preface.title: Introducing VRJConfig
preface.para: Configuring VR software for a particular hardware system can be a daunting taks due to the complexity and diversity of the environments and hardware in use. In addition to this, many users will need to switch between immersive VR hardware and desktop simulators during development, or between one hardware system and another.

VR Juggler's inherent flexibility increases this complexity. VR Juggler components such as displays and device drivers can be combined in many ways. For example, a configuration could mix simulated and real input devices. Or, hardware permitting, VR Juggler could use two separate head-mounted displays (HMDs) simultaneously. Input devices can be chained together, manipulated in a variety of ways, and mapped to different names. The possibilities are endless - but so are the potential pitfalls.

In order to be successful, the design of VR Juggler mandated the need for a simple yet flexible configuration system whereby individual configuation elements can be easily mixed together. In such an open environment, resulting configuration files can become extremely complex making editing configurations by hand can be a tedious task in which making mistakes is easy. Enter VRJConfig, a GUI configuration editing tool designed to provide a simple, concise view of a configuration while helping prevent many kinds of errors.
This part is provides an introduction to the basic features of the VRJConfig configuration editor.

chapter.title: The Philosophy Behind VRJConfig
chapter.para: The design of VRJConfig has been driven by a few simple ideas in the hope to come up with a simplified editor for complex configurations. The concept of a configuration has been broken down into two parts: the configuration data and the definition of how that data is laid out in a configuration file.

section.title: Configuration Elements
section.para: VRJConfig attempts to break down any complex configuration into a set of individual, independent configuration elements. Each element contains the information needed to configure a single piece of the software. There are many, many different types of configuration elements, each specialized to contain different information specific to the part of the software they represent.

section.title: Configuration Definitions
section.para: Given a file with a list of configuration elements, how do you know how to interpret the data? This is where configuration definitions come into play. Each configuration definition defines exactly what properties are allowed in a given element, how to interpret the data contained therein, what values properties should default to, and general metadata describing the purpose of the element.

chapter.title: Getting Started With a New Configuration
chapter.para: In this chapter, we will carefully walk through the creation of a new simple configuration completely from scratch. This should give you a good idea of what configuration definitions and elements are in addition to learning how to create and edit them in the VRJConfig editor.
